titleStmt.title: An efficient particle swarm approach for mixed-integer programming in reliability-redundancy optimization applications

affiliation.orgName: Industrial and Systems Engineering Graduate Program
Industrial and Systems Engineering Graduate Program

analytic.title: An efficient particle swarm approach for mixed-integer programming in reliability-redundancy optimization applications

biblStruct.note: Received 12 November 2007 Received in revised form 29 August 2008 Accepted 1 September 2008

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Reliability-redundancy optimization Particle swarm optimization Evolutionary algorithm Meta-heuristics PSO, particle swarm optimization
PSO-CO, particle swarm optimization with constriction factor
PSO-GC, Gaussian probability distribution and also chaotic sequences in particle swarm optimization

div.p: The reliability-redundancy optimization problems can involve the selection of components with multiple choices and redundancy levels that produce maximum benefits, and are subject to the cost, weight, and volume constraints. Many classical mathematical methods have failed in handling nonconvexities and nonsmoothness in reliability-redundancy optimization problems. As an alternative to the classical optimization approaches, the meta-heuristics have been given much attention by many researchers due to their ability to find an almost global optimal solutions. One of these meta-heuristics is the particle swarm optimization (PSO). PSO is a population-based heuristic optimization technique inspired by social behavior of bird flocking and fish schooling. This paper presents an efficient PSO algorithm based on Gaussian distribution and chaotic sequence (PSO-GC) to solve the reliabilityredundancy optimization problems. In this context, two examples in reliability-redundancy design problems are evaluated. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed PSO-GC is a promising optimization technique. PSO-GC performs well for the two examples of mixed-integer programming in reliability-redundancy applications considered in this paper. The solutions obtained by the PSO-GC are better than the previously best-known solutions available in the recent literature.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In 1952, the Advisory Group on the Reliability of Electronic Equipment defined the reliability in a broader sense: reliability indicates the probability implementing specific performance or function of products and achieving successfully the objectives within a time schedule under a certain environment [1]. A design engineer often tries to improve system reliability with a basic design, to the largest extent possible subject to constraints on any component attributes (cost, weight, and volume) of system [2]. The problem is to select the optimal combination of components and redundancy levels to meet system level constraints while maximizing system reliability.

Recently, many meta-heuristics [3,4], such as evolutionary algorithms [5][6][7][8][9][10][11][12][13], tabu search [14,15], ant colony optimization [16][17][18][19], artificial immune system [20], fuzzy system [21], and artificial neural networks [22] have been employed in reliability-redundancy optimization problems. One of these modern meta-heuristics is the particle swarm optimization (PSO).

PSO, first introduced by Kennedy and Eberhart [23,24], is a stochastic global optimization technique inspired by social behavior of bird flocking or fish schooling. It simulated the feature of bird flocking and fish schooling to configure the heuristic learning mechanism. PSO is initialized with a population of random solutions within the feasible range, called particles (individual). The learning procedure of PSO is that the solution of every individual particle is modified with the cause of its own best experience and other individuals' best experiences. In other words, the particles fly through the search space influenced by two factors: one is the individual's best position ever found (personal best); the other is the group's best position (global best). In this case, each particle in PSO flies through the search space with a velocity that is dynamically adjusted according to its own and its cognitive and social behaviors.

In canonical PSO, a uniform probability distribution to generate random numbers is used. However, the use of other probability distributions may improve the ability to fine-tuning or even to escape from local optima. In the meantime, it has been proposed the use of the Gaussian [25][26][27], Cauchy [28,29], exponential [30], Le ´vy [31] probability distribution functions, and chaotic sequences [32][33][34][35] to generate random numbers to updating the velocity equation in PSO. This paper employs the Gaussian probability distribution and also chaotic sequences in PSO (PSO-GC) design to solve the reliability-redundancy optimization problems. In this context, two examples in reliability-redundancy design are evaluated. The results of proposed PSO-GC algorithm, canonical PSO (PSO-CA), and PSO with constriction factor (PSO-CO) are compared. The novel PSO-GC algorithm outperforms and provide solutions when compared with PSO-CA, PSO-CO, and also other techniques presented in literature for the two reliability-redundancy optimization examples [36][37][38].

The remaining content of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, the reliability-redundancy optimization problem is introduced, while the concepts of PSO approaches are explained in Section 3. Section 4 presents the simulation results for two reliability-redundancy optimization problems. Finally, Section 5 contains the concluding remarks and further research.

div.head: Description of reliability-redundancy optimization problem
div.p: The goal of reliability engineering is to improve the reliability system. The reliability-redundancy optimizations are useful for system designs that are largely assembled and manufactured using off-the-shelf components, and also, have high reliability requirements [39].

A reliability-redundancy optimization problem can be formulated with system reliability as the objective function or in the constraint set. In this work, the reliability-redundancy allocation problem of maximizing the system reliability subject to multiple nonlinear constraints can be stated as a nonlinearly mixed-integer programming model in general form as follows:
div.formula: Maximize R s ¼ f ðr; nÞ,(1)
div.p: subject to gðr; nÞpl (2)
div.formula: 0pr i p1; r i 2 <; n i 2 Z þ ; 1pipm
div.p: where R s is the reliability of system, g is the set of constraint functions usually associated with system weight, volume and cost, r ¼ (r 1 ,r 2 ,r 3 , y, r m ) is the vector of the component reliabilities for the system, n ¼ (n 1 ,n 2 ,n 3 , y, n m ) is the vector of the redundancy allocation for the system; r i and n i are the reliability and the number of components in the ith subsystem, respectively; f( Á ) is the objective function for the overall system reliability; and l is the vector of resource limitation; m is the number of subsystems in the system. The goal is to determine the number of component and the components' reliability in each system so as to maximize the overall system reliability. The problem belongs to the category of constrained nonlinear mixed-integer optimization problems.

div.head: Example 1: complex (bridge) system
div.p: The first example problem used to demonstrate the efficiency of PSO approaches were proposed in [38,40,41]. Fig. 1 represents the complex (bridge) system analyzed in this paper.
The complex (bridge) system optimization problem can be stated as follows [38]:
div.formula: maximize f ðr; nÞ ¼ R 1 R 2 þ R 3 R 4 þ R 1 R 4 R 5 þ R 2 R 3 R 5 À R 1 R 2 R 3 R 4 À R 1 R 2 R 3 R 5 À R 1 R 2 R 4 R 5 À R 1 R 3 R 4 R 5 À R 2 R 3 R 4 R 5 þ 2R 1 R 2 R 3 R 4 R 5 (3
div.p: subject to the maximum velocity that each particle can make at each iteration x i ¼ [x i1 ,x i2 , y, x in ] T the position of the ith particle of population w i the weight of each component in subsystem i y 1 the output of He ´non map y 2 a signal of state in He ´non map C the upper limit on the cost of the system F the feasible region R s the system reliability S the search space V the upper limit on the sum of the subsystems' products of volume and weight Ud a uniformly-distributed random number within the range [0,1] W the upper limit on the weight of the system l i ¼ [l i1 ,l i2 , y, l in ] T the velocity of the ith particle ½n i þ e 0:25n i pC (5)
div.formula: g 1 ðr; nÞ ¼ X m i¼1 w i v 2 i n 2 i pV(4)

div.head: ARTICLE IN PRESS
div.formula: g 3 ðr; nÞ ¼ X m i¼1 w i n i e 0:25n i pW (6
div.p: where V is the upper limit on the sum of the subsystems' products of volume and weight, C is the upper limit on the cost of the system, and W is the upper limit on the weight of the system. Eqs. ( 4), ( 5) and ( 6) are constraints about the reliability, system cost and weight, respectively. On the other words, constraint given by Eq. ( 4) is a combination of weight, redundancy allocation and volume. Eq. ( 5) is a cost constraint, while Eq. ( 6) is a weight constraint. In this context, n i AZ, where Z is the space discrete of integers, and 0pr i p1, r i 2 <; where < is set of real numbers, 0pipm. The parameters b i and a i are physical features of system components. The input parameters defining the of the complex (bridge) system are shown in Table 1. The data shown in Table 1 are also available in [38,40,41].

div.head: Example 2: overspeed protection system for a gas turbine
div.p: To evaluate the performance of the PSO approaches for the mixed-integer nonlinear reliability design problem, the reliability-redundancy optimization problem of the overspeed protection system for a gas turbine [36][37][38] is also considered. Overspeed detection is continuously provided by the electrical and mechanical systems. When an overspeed occurs, it is necessary to cut off the fuel supply using control valves [36].
This problem is formulated as the following mixed-integer nonlinear programming problem, i.e., the problem can be stated as
div.formula: Maximize f ðr; nÞ ¼ Y m i¼1 ½1 À ð1 À r i Þ n i(7)
div.p: subject to
div.formula: g 1 ðr; nÞ ¼ X m i¼1 v i n 2 i pV(8)
g 2 ðr; nÞ ¼ X m i¼1 Cðr i Þ½n i þ e 0:25n i pC(9)
g 3 ðr; nÞ ¼ X m i¼1 w i n i e 0:25n i pW (10
1pn i p10; n i 2 Z þ
div.p: where Z is the space discrete of positive integers, 0:
div.formula: 5pr i p1 À 10 À6 ; r i 2 <
div.p: where v i is the volume of each component in subsystem i; V is the upper limit on the sum of the subsystems' products of volume and weight; C is the upper limit on the cost of the system;
div.formula: Cðr i Þ ¼ a i ½ÀT= lnðr i Þ b i
div.p: is the cost of each component with reliability r i at subsystem i; T is the operating time during which the component must not fail; and W is the upper limit on the weight of the system. The input parameters defining the of the overspeed protection system for a gas turbine are shown in Table 2. The data shown in Table 2 are also available in [36][37][38].

div.head: Optimization using PSO algorithms
div.p: PSO is a population-based heuristic global search algorithm based on the social interaction and individual experience. In essence, PSO mimics the collective learning of individuals when they are in groups, observed through natural behaviors of bird flocks and fish schools. In these groups, there is a leader who guides the movement of the whole swarm. The movement of every individual is based on the leader and on his own knowledge. In general, it can be said that the model that PSO is inspired assumes that the behavior of every particle is a compromise between its individual memory and a collective memory.

In PSO, a point (individual) in the problem space is referred to as particles, is a candidate solution to the optimization problem at hand. Each particle in population (named swarm in PSO) is initialized with a random position and search velocity. Each particle flies through the problem space and keeps track of its position, velocity and fitness. Moreover, its position (i.e. a solution) and velocity (i.e. change pattern of the solution) are adjusted according to its own experience and social cooperation by its fitness to the environment.

During this iterative process, the behavior of a particle is a compromise among three possible alternatives: (i) following its current pattern of exploration, (ii) going back towards its best previous position, and (iii) going towards the best historic value of all the particles. A representation of procedure of a classical PSO is presented in Fig. 2.

In this section, the PSO approaches validated in this work are described. The first one is the canonical PSO, which is presented in Section 3.1. In Section 3.2, the PSO based on constriction coefficient approach is detailed. The third one is the PSO technique based on Gaussian distribution and chaotic sequence is described in Section 3.3.

div.head: Standard or canonical PSO approach (CA-PSO)
div.p: The procedure for implementing the global version of canonical PSO is given by the following steps [33,34]:

Step 1. Initialization random of positions and velocities: Initialize a population of particles with random positions and velocities in the n-dimensional problem space using a uniform probability distribution function at iteration t ¼ 1.

Step 2. Evaluation of particle's fitness: Evaluate each particle's objective function value (fitness). In this paper, the deal of PSO-CA is the maximization of objective function. Step 3. Comparison to p best (personal best): Compare each particle's fitness with the particle's p best . If the current value is better than p best , then set the p best value equal to the current value and the p best location equal to the current location in n-dimensional space.

div.head: ARTICLE IN PRESS
div.p: Step 4. Comparison to g best (global best): Compare the fitness with the population's overall previous best. If the current value is better than g best , then reset g best to the current particle's array index and value.

Step 5. Updating of each particle's velocity and position: Each particle tries to modify its position using the current velocity and its distance from its own best position and the global best particle. The modification of the velocity, v i , and position of the particle, x i , can be represented by Eqs. ( 11) and ( 12)
div.formula: l i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ ol i ðtÞ þ c 1 udðp i ðtÞ À x i ðtÞÞ þ c 2 Udðp g ðtÞ À x i ðtÞÞ (11) x i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ x i ðtÞ þ Dtl i ðt þ 1Þ (12
div.p: where o is the inertia weight; i ¼ 1,2, y, N indicates the index of particles; t ¼ 1,2, y, t max indicates the iterations (generations); t max is the maximum number of allowable iterations; l i ¼ [l i1 ,l i2 , y, l in ] T stands for the velocity of the ith particle, x i ¼ [x i1 ,x i2 , y,

x in ] T stands for the position of the ith particle of population, and p i ¼ [p i1 ,p i2 , y, p in ] T represents the best previous position of the ith particle. Positive constants c 1 and c 2 are the cognitive learning and social learning rates, respectively, which are the acceleration constants responsible for varying the particle velocity towards p best and g best , respectively. The index of the best particle among all the particles in the population is represented by the symbol g. The first relation in Eq. ( 11) is used to calculate ith particle's new velocity by taking into consideration three terms: the particle's previous velocity, the distance between the particle's best previous and current position, and, lastly, the distance between swarm's best experience (the position of the best particle in the swarm) and ith particle's current position. The velocity in Eq. ( 11) is also limited by a maximum, v max , meaning the maximum jump that each particle can make at each iteration (generation). The selected value for v max should not be too high to avoid oscillations, or too low to explore sufficiently and the particle becomes trapped in a local optimal solution.

In Eq. ( 11), the value given to the inertia weight affects the type of search in the following way: a large w will direct the PSO for a global search while a small w will direct the PSO for a local search. This parameter can vary linearly from a larger value to a smaller value in order to make the search global in the early run and local in the end of the run.

Considering these concerns, Shi and Eberhart [42] have found improvements in the performance of the PSO with a linearly varying inertia weight over the generations. The mathematical representation of this concept is given by
div.formula: o ¼ ðo 1 À o 2 Þ ðt max À tÞ t max þ o 2(13)
div.p: where o 1 and o 2 are the initial and final values of the inertia weight, respectively. Through empirical studies, Shi and Eberhart [42] have observed that the good solution can be improved by varying the value of o from 0.9 at the beginning of the search to 0.4 at the end of the search for most problems. Then by Eq. ( 12) the ith particle flies towards a new position according to its previous position and its velocity, considering Dt ¼ 1. Fig. 3 shows a representation of a searching point by PSO algorithm.

Step 6. Repeating the evolutionary cycle: If a predefined stopping criterion is met, usually a sufficiently good fitness or a maximum number of iterations (generations), then output g best and its objective value; otherwise set t ¼ t+1 and go back to Step 2.

div.head: PSO using constriction coefficient approach (PSO-CO)
div.p: Eq. ( 11) of velocity updating for the canonical PSO algorithm can be considered as a kind of difference equation. A particle's velocity is an important parameter because it determines the resolution about the solution regions. The choice of a too small value for v max can cause very small updating of velocities and positions of particles at each iteration. Hence, the algorithm may take a long time to converge and faces the problem of getting stuck to local minima. To overcome these situations, researchers [43,44] have recently proposed improved velocity update rules employing a constriction factor w. In doing so, the velocity equation is updated according to l i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ w½l i ðtÞ þ c 1 udðp i ðtÞ À x i ðtÞÞ þ c 2 Udðp g ðtÞ À x i ðtÞÞ (14) By using a constriction coefficient w expressed as

div.head: ARTICLE IN PRESS
div.formula: w ¼ 2 j2 À j À ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ffi j 2 À 4j p j(15)
div.p: with the parameter j ¼ c 1 +c 2 , j44 and w is a function of c 1 and c 2 . Typically, c 1 and c 2 are both set to be 2.05. Thus, j is set to 4.1 and the constriction coefficient w is 0.729. Clerc and Kennedy [43] found that the system behavior could be controlled so that the system behavior has the following features: (i) the system does not diverge in a real value region and finally can converge; and (ii) the system can search different regions efficiently by avoiding premature convergence. The PSO-CO uses Eqs. ( 14), (15), and also Eq. ( 12) to update the position of particles in swarm. This modification are simplistic in a sense that they only (gradually) reduce the parameter value(s) without affecting the structure of PSO.

div.head: Framework of novel PSO method using Gaussian distribution and chaotic sequences (PSO-GC)
div.p: In PSO-CA and PSO-CO methods, a uniform probability distribution to generate random numbers ud and Ud is adopted in velocity equation. The use of Gaussian probability distribution [25][26][27] can improve the ability to fine-tuning or even to escape from local optima in PSO design. The mechanisms of Gaussian mutation operations have been studied by Yao et al. [45] and Chellapilla [46]. They pointed out that Gaussian mutation in evolutionary algorithms is promising at fine-grained search.

In other way, the PSO-CA and PSO-CO methods cannot ensure the optimization's ergodicity entirely in phase space, because it is random in this method. An alternative is the implementation of a PSO approach based on chaotic sequences. Chaos is a kind of characteristic that often exists in nonlinear dynamic systems, which has been studied and applied in many fields, such as engineering and mathematics [47][48][49]. Chaotic motion is a kind of highly unstable motion of deterministic systems in finite phase space and it is especially used as a component of effective optimization algorithms [32][33][34][35][50][51][52][53][54] relying on its university, randomcity and sensitivity dependence on the initial conditions of chaotic mapping.

Inspired by the Gaussian probability distribution and chaotic motion ideas, this paper provides a novel combined optimization method, which introduces chaotic mapping into PSO based on He ´non map [55] so as to improve the global convergence and also a Gaussian probability distribution to improve the local convergence. It is a promising to achieve trade-off between exploration and exploitation and, moreover, effective way of dealing with the updating of velocity in PSO-CO. He ´non's map is a simplified version of the Poincare ´map of the Lorenz system [47]. The He ´non map [55] is given by
div.formula: y 1 ðkÞ ¼ 1 À aðy 1 ðk À 1ÞÞ 2 þ y 2 ðk À 1Þ (16
y 2 ðkÞ ¼ by 1 ðk À 1Þ (17
div.p: where k is the iteration number. The He ´non map is used in this work for a ¼ 1.4 and b ¼ 0.3 (the values for which the He ´non map has a strange attractor).
The proposed approach called PSO-GC is given by the following pseudocode:

div.head: If t41
div.p: If f1 À ððminðf Þ À f i ðr; nÞÞ=ðminðf Þ À maxðf ÞÞÞgox % chaotic sequence based on He ´non map in velocity updating
div.formula: l i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ w½l i ðtÞ þ c 1 h i ðp i ðtÞ À x i ðtÞÞ þ c 2 H i ðp g ðtÞ À x i ðtÞÞ (18
div.p: Else If % Gaussian distribution in velocity updating
div.formula: l i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ w½l i ðtÞ þ c 1 G i ðp i ðtÞ À x i ðtÞÞ þ c 2 Udðp g ðtÞ À x i ðtÞÞ(19)
div.p: End If Else If % use Eq. ( 19) in iteration t ¼ 1
div.formula: l i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ w½l i ðtÞ þ c 1 G i ðp i ðtÞ À x i ðtÞÞ þ c 2 Udðp g ðtÞ À x iðtÞÞ

div.head: End If
div.p: where min(f) and max(f) are the worst and best objective function values (maximization problem) of the swarm at iteration t, respectively. The f i (r, n) is the objective function value of ith particle; x is a constant positive value in range [0,1]; G i denotes a

Gaussian random number scaled in the range [0;1] and is generated a new for each ith particle; h i and H i are generated by He ´non map given by Eqs. ( 18) and ( 19) normalized in the range [0,1]. Occasionally, the swarm of particles can converge onto one point, which means min(f) ¼ max(f). In this case, the value {1À[min(f)Àf i (r, n)]/[min(f)Àmax(f)]} of arbitrary particle is set to 1. The best particle presents the smaller value than the other particles in swarm for the expression described by {1À[min(f
div.formula: )Àf i (r, n)]/[min(f)Àmax(f)]}.
div.p: Based on the pseudocode of PSO-GC, it can be noted that the good particles in swarm tend to perform exploitation to refine results by local search using Gaussian distribution, while bad particles tend to perform large modification to explore space with large step using a chaotic sequence since the essence of keeping diversity is to prevent or perturb the swarm. In other words, PSO-GC can provide a way to maintain population diversity and to sustain good convergence capacity.

div.head: Constraints handling with evaluated PSO approaches
div.p: A key factor in the application of PSO algorithms to solve the reliability-redundancy optimization problems is how the algorithm handles the constraints relating to the problem. Over the last few decades, several methods have been proposed to handle constraints in evolutionary algorithms [56][57][58][59]. These methods can be grouped into four categories: methods that preserve the feasibility of solutions, penalty-based methods, methods that clearly distinguish between feasible and unfeasible solutions and hybrid methods.

When PSO algorithms are used for constrained optimization problems, it is common to handle constraints using concepts of penalty functions (which penalize unfeasible solutions), i.e., one attempt to solve an unconstrained problem in the search space S using a modified objective function f (we are maximizing function for the overall system reliability in this paper) such as
div.formula: max f ðx i Þ ¼ f ðx i Þ; if x i 2 F f ðx i Þ À penaltyðx i Þ; otherwise: ((20)
div.p: where x i are solutions obtained by PSO approaches, i.e. the position of the ith particle of population; penalty(x i ) is zero and no constraint is violated; otherwise it is positive. The penalty function is usually based on a distance measured to the nearest solution in the feasible region F or to the effort to repair the solution.

In this work, the penalty-based method proposed in [38] (details in Section 2.3 of [38]) was used in all PSO designs for infeasible solutions (constraint violation). The adopted approach is used to convert a constrained problem to an unconstrained one by modifying the search space. A penalty value is defined to take the constrained violation into account. In method proposed in [38], the terms l are subtracted (maximization problem) of objective function f(r, n) if g(r, n)4l.

div.head: Computation results
div.p: In this section, it turns to the description and analysis of the results obtained by the optimization tests.

div.head: Parameter settings
div.p: Two examples described in Sections 2.1 and 2.2 are employed. Each particle of swarm in PSO-CA, PSO-CO, and PSO-GC approaches uses the variables vectors n and r, where the boundaries are given in Section 2. In this paper, during the evolution process, the integer variables n i are treated as real variables, and in evaluating the objective function, the real values are transformed to the nearest integer values.

Each optimization method was implemented in Matlab (MathWorks). All the programs were run on a 3.2 GHz Pentium IV processor with 2 GB of Random Access Memory (RAM). In order to eliminate stochastic discrepancy, in each case study, 50 independent runs were made for each of the optimization methods involving 50 different initial trial solutions for each optimization method.
For each testing problem, the parameters of the PSO-CA are set as follows:
div.formula: c 1 ¼ c 2 ¼ 2.

div.head: Results and discussion for the complex (bridge) system
div.p: The swarm size is set to 90 and the stopping criterion t max was 150 iterations in all PSO algorithms for the complex (bridge) system. In other words, all PSO algorithms adopt 13,500 cost function evaluations in each run.

Simulation results of all PSO schemes for the complex (bridge) system are listed in Table 3. In terms of mean and best (g best of all runs) f(r, n) results, the PSO-GC approach outperforms PSO-CA and PSO-CO. The best results obtained for the complex (bridge) system using PSO-GC was 0.99988957, as shown in Table 4.

Table 5 compared the results obtained in this paper for the complex (bridge) system with those of other studies reported in the literature. Note that in complex (bridge) system case, the best result reported here using PSO-GC was comparatively lower than recent studies presented in the recent literature. By using Maximum Possible Improvement (MPI) index given by MPI (%) ¼ [R s (PSO-GC)ÀR s (other)]/[1ÀR s (other)] and presented in Table 5, it shows the PSO-GC made improvements in terms of reliability found by other optimization approaches in literature.

div.head: Results and discussion for the overspeed protection system for a gas turbine
div.p: The swarm size is set to 15 and the stopping criterion t max was 150 iterations in all PSO algorithms for the overspeed protection system for a gas turbine. All PSO algorithms adopt 2250 cost function evaluations in each run.

Statistical analyses of all PSO schemes in 50 runs for the overspeed protection system are summarized in Table 6. By using the results in Table 6, in terms of mean and best (g best of all runs) f(r, n) results, the solutions of PSO-GC are just slightly better than the solution found by PSO-CA and PSO-CO approaches for the overspeed protection system. In addition, the standard deviation of the results by PSO approaches in 50 independent runs is also very small.

The best results obtained for the overspeed protection system using PSO-GC was 0.999953, as shown in Table 7. From Table 8, it can conclude that a best solution found by PSO-GC for the overspeed protection system has a slight advantage over the other solvers reported in the literature.

div.head: Conclusion and further research
div.p: PSO is one of the most recent stochastic methods developed for solving optimization problems. The current study investigates the combination of Gaussian distribution and chaotic sequence in PSO design, and the performance of the proposed PSO-GC is compared with PSO-CA, PSO-CO, and other results presented in literature for two cases studies including discrete and continuous decision variables in reliability engineering field.

Simulation results presented in Tables 3-8 reveal that PSO-GC scheme presented improvements upon the effectiveness and efficiency and also obtained a good trade-off between exploitation in Gaussian distribution and exploration by chaotic sequences.

The PSO-GC was demonstrated to be a promising and viable tool to solve reliability-redundancy optimization problems. Furthermore, a number of improvements and extensions are currently being investigated by the author related to benchmark problems in reliability engineering field.
